an4.61:1.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an4.61:1.1.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an4.61:2.1.pli: “Cattārome, gahapati, dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dullabhā lokasmiṃ.
an4.61:2.1.eng: “Householder, these four things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable are hard to get in the world.

an4.61:2.3.pli: Bhogā me uppajjantu sahadhammenāti, ayaṃ paṭhamo dhammo iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ.
an4.61:2.3.eng: The first thing is the wish: ‘May wealth come to me by legitimate means!’

an4.61:3.1.pli: Bhoge laddhā sahadhammena yaso me āgacchatu saha ñātīhi saha upajjhāyehīti, ayaṃ dutiyo dhammo iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ.
an4.61:3.1.eng: The second thing, having got wealth by legitimate means, is the wish: ‘May fame come to me, together with my family and teachers.’

an4.61:4.1.pli: Bhoge laddhā sahadhammena yasaṃ laddhā saha ñātīhi saha upajjhāyehi ciraṃ jīvāmi dīghamāyuṃ pālemīti, ayaṃ tatiyo dhammo iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ.
an4.61:4.1.eng: The third thing, having got wealth and fame, is the wish: ‘May I live long, keeping alive for a long time!’

an4.61:5.1.pli: Bhoge laddhā sahadhammena yasaṃ laddhā saha ñātīhi saha upajjhāyehi ciraṃ jīvitvā dīghamāyuṃ pāletvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjāmīti, ayaṃ catuttho dhammo iṭṭho kanto manāpo dullabho lokasmiṃ.
an4.61:5.1.eng: The fourth thing, having got wealth, fame, and long life, is the wish: ‘When my body breaks up, after death, may I be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm!’

an4.61:5.2.pli: Ime kho, gahapati, cattāro dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dullabhā lokasmiṃ.
an4.61:5.2.eng: These are the four things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable, but hard to get in the world.

an4.61:6.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, gahapati, catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ dullabhānaṃ lokasmiṃ cattāro dhammā paṭilābhāya saṃvattanti.
an4.61:6.1.eng: These next four things lead to the getting of those four things.

an4.61:6.3.eng: Accomplishment in faith, ethics, generosity, and wisdom.

an4.61:7.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in faith?

an4.61:7.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
an4.61:7.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

an4.61:7.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi, satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an4.61:7.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an4.61:7.4.eng: This is called accomplishment in faith.

an4.61:8.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in ethics?

an4.61:8.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe… surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
an4.61:8.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an4.61:8.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in ethics.

an4.61:9.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in generosity?

an4.61:9.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vosaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
an4.61:9.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an4.61:9.3.eng: This is called accomplishment in generosity.

an4.61:10.1.eng: And what is accomplishment in wisdom?

an4.61:10.2.pli: Abhijjhāvisamalobhābhibhūtena, gahapati, cetasā viharanto akiccaṃ karoti, kiccaṃ aparādheti.
an4.61:10.2.eng: When your heart is mastered by covetousness and immoral greed, you do what you shouldn’t, and fail to do what you should.

an4.61:10.3.pli: Akiccaṃ karonto kiccaṃ aparādhento yasā ca sukhā ca dhaṃsati.
an4.61:10.3.eng: Your fame and happiness fall to dust.

an4.61:10.4.pli: Byāpādābhibhūtena, gahapati, cetasā viharanto akiccaṃ karoti, kiccaṃ aparādheti.
an4.61:10.4.eng: When your heart is mastered by ill will …

an4.61:10.5.pli: Akiccaṃ karonto kiccaṃ aparādhento yasā ca sukhā ca dhaṃsati.

an4.61:10.6.pli: Thinamiddhābhibhūtena, gahapati, cetasā viharanto akiccaṃ karoti kiccaṃ aparādheti.

an4.61:10.7.pli: Akiccaṃ karonto kiccaṃ aparādhento yasā ca sukhā ca dhaṃsati.

an4.61:10.8.pli: Uddhaccakukkuccābhibhūtena, gahapati, cetasā viharanto akiccaṃ karoti, kiccaṃ aparādheti.

an4.61:10.9.pli: Akiccaṃ karonto kiccaṃ aparādhento yasā ca sukhā ca dhaṃsati.

an4.61:10.10.pli: Vicikicchābhibhūtena, gahapati, cetasā viharanto akiccaṃ karoti, kiccaṃ aparādheti.
an4.61:10.10.eng: doubt, you do what you shouldn’t, and fail to do what you should.

an4.61:10.11.pli: Akiccaṃ karonto kiccaṃ aparādhento yasā ca sukhā ca dhaṃsati.
an4.61:10.11.eng: Your fame and happiness fall to dust.

an4.61:11.1.pli: Sa kho so, gahapati, ariyasāvako abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā abhijjhāvisamalobhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati.
an4.61:11.1.eng: Knowing that ‘covetousness and immoral greed are corruptions of the mind’, that noble disciple gives them up.

an4.61:11.2.pli: Byāpādo cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā byāpādaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati.

an4.61:11.3.pli: Thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati.

an4.61:11.4.pli: Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā uddhaccakukkuccaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati.

an4.61:11.5.pli: Vicikicchā cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā vicikicchaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati.
an4.61:11.5.eng: ‘doubt is a corruption of the mind’, that noble disciple gives it up.

an4.61:12.1.pli: Yato ca kho, gahapati, ariyasāvakassa abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti.
an4.61:12.1.eng: When a noble disciple has given up these things,

an4.61:12.2.pli: Byāpādo cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā byāpādo cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti.

an4.61:12.3.pli: Thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā thinamiddhaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti.

an4.61:12.4.pli: Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā uddhaccakukkuccaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti.

an4.61:12.5.pli: Vicikicchā cittassa upakkilesoti, iti viditvā vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti.

an4.61:12.6.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, gahapati, ariyasāvako mahāpañño puthupañño āpātadaso paññāsampanno.
an4.61:12.6.eng: they’re called ‘a noble disciple of great wisdom, of widespread wisdom, who sees what matters, and is accomplished in wisdom’.

an4.61:12.7.eng: This is called accomplishment in wisdom.

an4.61:12.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, gahapati, catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ dullabhānaṃ lokasmiṃ ime cattāro dhammā paṭilābhāya saṃvattanti.
an4.61:12.8.eng: These are the four things that lead to the getting of the four things, which are likable, desirable, and agreeable, but hard to get in the world.

an4.61:13.1.pli: Sa kho so, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi cattāri pattakammāni kattā hoti.
an4.61:13.1.eng: There are four fitting deeds that a noble disciple does with the legitimate wealth he has earned by his efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.

an4.61:13.3.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati.
an4.61:13.3.eng: To start with, with his legitimate wealth he makes himself happy and pleased, keeping himself properly happy.

an4.61:13.4.pli: Mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati.
an4.61:13.4.eng: He makes his mother and father happy …

an4.61:13.5.pli: Puttadāradāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati.
an4.61:13.5.eng: He makes his children, partners, bondservants, workers, and staff happy …

an4.61:13.6.pli: Mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati.
an4.61:13.6.eng: He makes his friends and colleagues happy …

an4.61:13.7.pli: Idamassa paṭhamaṃ ṭhānagataṃ hoti pattagataṃ āyatanaso paribhuttaṃ.
an4.61:13.7.eng: This is his first expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.

an4.61:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi yā tā honti āpadā aggito vā udakato vā rājato vā corato vā appiyato vā dāyādato, tathārūpāsu āpadāsu pariyodhāya saṃvattati.
an4.61:14.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he defends himself against threats from such things as fire, flood, rulers, bandits, or unloved heirs.

an4.61:14.3.pli: Idamassa dutiyaṃ ṭhānagataṃ hoti pattagataṃ āyatanaso paribhuttaṃ.
an4.61:14.3.eng: This is his second expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.

an4.61:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi pañcabaliṃ kattā hoti—
an4.61:15.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he makes five spirit-offerings:

an4.61:15.2.eng: to relatives, guests, ancestors, king, and deities.

an4.61:15.3.pli: Idamassa tatiyaṃ ṭhānagataṃ hoti pattagataṃ āyatanaso paribhuttaṃ.
an4.61:15.3.eng: This is his third expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.

an4.61:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā madappamādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṃ damenti, ekamattānaṃ samenti, ekamattānaṃ parinibbāpenti, tathārūpesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
an4.61:16.1.eng: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he establishes an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins—those who refrain from intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves—that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

an4.61:16.2.pli: Idamassa catutthaṃ ṭhānagataṃ hoti pattagataṃ āyatanaso paribhuttaṃ.
an4.61:16.2.eng: This is his fourth expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.

an4.61:17.1.pli: Sa kho so, gahapati, ariyasāvako uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi imāni cattāri pattakammāni kattā hoti.
an4.61:17.1.eng: ’these are the four fitting deeds that a noble disciple does with the legitimate wealth he has earned by his efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.

an4.61:17.2.pli: Yassa kassaci, gahapati, aññatra imehi catūhi pattakammehi bhogā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ime vuccanti, gahapati, bhogā aṭṭhānagatā apattagatā anāyatanaso paribhuttā.
an4.61:17.2.eng: Whatever wealth is spent on something other than these four fitting deeds is said to not be expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.

an4.61:17.3.pli: Yassa kassaci, gahapati, imehi catūhi pattakammehi bhogā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ime vuccanti, gahapati, bhogā ṭhānagatā pattagatā āyatanaso paribhuttāti.
an4.61:17.3.eng: But whatever wealth is spent on these four fitting deeds is said to be expenditure in an appropriate sphere on a deserved and fitting cause.

an4.61:18.1.eng: ‘I’ve enjoyed my wealth, <j>supporting those who depend on me;

an4.61:18.5.eng: I have served the ethical and

an4.61:19.4.eng: I don’t regret what I’ve done.’

an4.61:20.1.eng: A mortal man who recollects this

an4.61:20.2.eng: stands firm in the teaching of the noble ones.

an4.61:20.4.eng: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

an4.62:1.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an4.62:1.1.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an4.62:2.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, gahapati, sukhāni adhigamanīyāni gihinā kāmabhoginā kālena kālaṃ samayena samayaṃ upādāya.
an4.62:2.1.eng: “Householder, these four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.

an4.62:2.3.eng: The happiness of ownership, using wealth, debtlessness, and blamelessness.

an4.62:3.1.eng: And what is the happiness of ownership?

an4.62:3.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, kulaputtassa bhogā honti uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatā bāhābalaparicitā sedāvakkhittā dhammikā dhammaladdhā.
an4.62:3.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman owns legitimate wealth that he has earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.

an4.62:3.3.pli: So ‘bhogā me atthi uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatā bāhābalaparicitā sedāvakkhittā dhammikā dhammaladdhā’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
an4.62:3.3.eng: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.

an4.62:3.4.eng: This is called ‘the happiness of ownership’.

an4.62:4.1.eng: And what is the happiness of using wealth?

an4.62:4.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, kulaputto uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi paribhuñjati puññāni ca karoti.
an4.62:4.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth, and makes merit with it.

an4.62:4.3.pli: So ‘uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi paribhuñjāmi puññāni ca karomī’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
an4.62:4.3.eng: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.

an4.62:4.4.eng: This is called ‘the happiness of using wealth’.

an4.62:5.1.eng: And what is the happiness of debtlessness?

an4.62:5.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, kulaputto na kassaci kiñci dhāreti appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā.
an4.62:5.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman owes no debt, large or small, to anyone.

an4.62:5.3.pli: So ‘na kassaci kiñci dhāremi appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
an4.62:5.3.eng: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.

an4.62:5.4.eng: This is called ‘the happiness of debtlessness’.

an4.62:6.1.eng: And what is the happiness of blamelessness?

an4.62:6.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako anavajjena kāyakammena samannāgato hoti, anavajjena vacīkammena samannāgato hoti, anavajjena manokammena samannāgato hoti.
an4.62:6.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has blameless conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an4.62:6.3.pli: So ‘anavajjenamhi kāyakammena samannāgato, anavajjena vacīkammena samannāgato, anavajjena manokammena samannāgato’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
an4.62:6.3.eng: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.

an4.62:6.4.eng: This is called ‘the happiness of blamelessness’.

an4.62:6.5.pli: Imāni kho, gahapati, cattāri sukhāni adhigamanīyāni gihinā kāmabhoginā kālena kālaṃ samayena samayaṃ upādāyāti.
an4.62:6.5.eng: These four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.

an4.62:7.2.eng: and the extra happiness of possession,

an4.62:7.3.eng: a mortal enjoying the happiness of using wealth,

an4.62:8.1.eng: Discerning clearly, a clever person knows

an4.62:8.3.eng: the other kind is not worth a sixteenth part

an4.63:1.1.pli: “Sabrahmakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an4.63:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with divinity.

an4.63:1.2.pli: Sapubbācariyakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni, yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an4.63:1.2.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with the first tutors.

an4.63:1.3.pli: Sapubbadevatāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an4.63:1.3.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with the elder gods.

an4.63:1.4.pli: Sāhuneyyakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
an4.63:1.4.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.

an4.63:2.1.eng: ‘Divinity’ is a term for your parents.

an4.63:2.2.eng: ‘First tutors’ is a term for your parents.

an4.63:2.3.eng: ‘Elder gods’ is a term for your parents.

an4.63:2.4.eng: ‘Worthy of an offering dedicated to the gods’ is a term for your parents.

an4.63:2.6.pli: Bahukārā, bhikkhave, mātāpitaro, puttānaṃ āpādakā posakā imassa lokassa dassetāroti.
an4.63:2.6.eng: Parents are very helpful to their children, they raise them, nurture them, and show them the world.

an4.63:3.3.eng: They’re worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods <j>from their children,

an4.63:4.2.eng: would revere them and honor them

an4.63:5.3.eng: they’re praised in this life by the astute,

an4.63:5.4.eng: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

an4.64:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.64:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, someone with four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.64:1.3.pli: Pāṇātipātī hoti, adinnādāyī hoti, kāmesumicchācārī hoti, musāvādī hoti—
an4.64:1.3.eng: They kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, and lie.

an4.64:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ nirayeti.
an4.64:1.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.64:2.4.eng: astute people don’t praise these things.”

an4.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.65:1.3.pli: Rūpappamāṇo rūpappasanno, ghosappamāṇo ghosappasanno, lūkhappamāṇo lūkhappasanno, dhammappamāṇo dhammappasanno—
an4.65:1.3.eng: There are those whose estimation of and confidence in others is based on their appearance, on their voice, on their mortification, and on principle.

an4.65:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an4.65:1.4.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.

an4.65:2.2.eng: and those swayed by a voice,

an4.65:2.3.eng: are full of desire and greed;

an4.65:3.3.eng: the fool shut in on every side,

an4.65:3.4.eng: gets carried away by a voice.

an4.65:4.4.eng: they’re also carried away by a voice.

an4.65:5.4.eng: they don’t get carried away by a voice.”

an4.66:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.66:1.3.eng: The greedy, the hateful, the delusional, and the conceited.

an4.66:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an4.66:1.4.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.

an4.66:2.1.eng: Full of desire for desirable things,

an4.66:3.1.eng: Born of greed, born of hate,

an4.66:4.1.eng: If you act out of these qualities, <j>that’s what you become.

an4.66:4.3.eng: are blind, with no eyes to see,

an4.66:4.4.eng: and they never imagine that this could be so.”

an4.67:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an4.67:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an4.67:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sāvatthiyaṃ aññataro bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṅkato hoti.
an4.67:1.2.eng: Now, at that time a monk in Sāvatthī passed away due to a snake bite.

an4.67:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an4.67:1.3.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an4.67:1.4.pli: “idha, bhante, sāvatthiyaṃ aññataro bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṅkato”ti.
an4.67:1.4.eng: “Sir, a monk in Sāvatthī has passed away due to a snake bite.”

an4.67:2.1.pli: “Na hi nūna so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phari.
an4.67:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, that monk mustn’t have spread a mind of love to the four royal snake families.

an4.67:2.2.pli: Sace hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phareyya, na hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṃ kareyya.
an4.67:2.2.eng: If he had, he wouldn’t have died due to a snake bite.

an4.67:3.2.pli: Virūpakkhaṃ ahirājakulaṃ, erāpathaṃ ahirājakulaṃ, chabyāputtaṃ ahirājakulaṃ, kaṇhāgotamakaṃ ahirājakulaṃ.
an4.67:3.2.eng: The royal snake families of Virūpakkha, Erāpatha, Chabyāputta, and Kaṇhāgotamaka. …

an4.67:3.3.pli: Na hi nūna so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phari.

an4.67:3.4.pli: Sace hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phareyya, na hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṃ kareyya.

an4.67:4.1.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena pharituṃ attaguttiyā attarakkhāya attaparittāyāti.
an4.67:4.1.eng: Mendicants, I urge you to spread a mind of love to the four royal snake families, for your own safety, security, and protection.

an4.67:7.1.eng: May the footless not harm me!

an4.67:7.2.eng: May I not be harmed by the two-footed!

an4.67:7.3.eng: May the four-footed not harm me!

an4.67:7.4.eng: May I not be harmed by the many-footed!

an4.67:8.1.eng: All sentient beings, all living things,

an4.67:8.3.eng: may they see only nice things,

an4.67:8.4.eng: may bad not come to anyone.

an4.67:10.3.pli: Katā me rakkhā katā me parittā,
an4.67:10.3.eng: I’ve made this safeguard, I’ve made this protection:

an4.67:10.5.eng: And so I revere the Blessed One,

an4.67:10.6.eng: I revere the seven perfectly awakened Buddhas.”

an4.68:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
an4.68:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.

an4.68:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā devadattaṃ ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
an4.68:1.2.eng: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:

an4.68:1.3.eng: “Possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.

an4.68:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kadalī attavadhāya phalaṃ deti, parābhavāya phalaṃ deti;

an4.68:2.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.

an4.68:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, veḷu attavadhāya phalaṃ deti, parābhavāya phalaṃ deti;

an4.68:3.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.

an4.68:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, naḷo attavadhāya phalaṃ deti, parābhavāya phalaṃ deti;
an4.68:4.1.eng: or a reed, all of which bear fruit to their own ruin and downfall …

an4.68:4.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi.

an4.68:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, assatarī attavadhāya gabbhaṃ gaṇhāti, parābhavāya gabbhaṃ gaṇhāti;
an4.68:5.1.eng: It’s like a mule, which becomes pregnant to its own ruin and downfall.

an4.68:5.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, attavadhāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādi, parābhavāya devadattassa lābhasakkārasiloko udapādīti.
an4.68:5.2.eng: In the same way, possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.

an4.68:6.1.eng: The banana plant is destroyed by its own fruit,

an4.68:6.2.eng: as are the bamboo and the reed.
